snippet.textDisplay: It can be hard on your ears, and only a "low resistance mask". i.e. it prevents you from giving the virus to others, but doesn't prevent you from getting it. If you take the exact same mask and connect the rubber bands behind your neck using a small cheap carabiner or tie of some sort, then you increase the comfort on your ears and dramatically increase the resistance & effectiveness of the mask. Plus you can use stiffer rubber bands (3 inch long 1/4 inch wide ones work good), denser cloth, put paper towels or blue shop towels in, and other things behind it to increase the resistance (paper towels also allow you to throw them away and wash the rest of the mask less). For good resistance you need the rubber bands pulling the mask decently into your face, for a good seal on the sides, at a mildly uncomfortable level.
snippet.textOriginal: It can be hard on your ears, and only a "low resistance mask". i.e. it prevents you from giving the virus to others, but doesn't prevent you from getting it. If you take the exact same mask and connect the rubber bands behind your neck using a small cheap carabiner or tie of some sort, then you increase the comfort on your ears and dramatically increase the resistance & effectiveness of the mask. Plus you can use stiffer rubber bands (3 inch long 1/4 inch wide ones work good), denser cloth, put paper towels or blue shop towels in, and other things behind it to increase the resistance (paper towels also allow you to throw them away and wash the rest of the mask less). For good resistance you need the rubber bands pulling the mask decently into your face, for a good seal on the sides, at a mildly uncomfortable level.

snippet.textDisplay:
OK, couple of replies to some of the naysayers, etc.
1. This is NOT the face mask to use if you're doing surgery. The IS the face mask to use when you're going out to get groceries, etc. The key word is PROTECTION, *NOT* PREVENTION. It's not so much to PREVENT you from getting the virus; it's to minimize the chances that you will catch it OR pass it on, if you're asymptomatic.
2. Regardless of if you're using new bandannas or cutting up used clothing or sheets to use, make sure the material is 100% cotton. DO NOT USE COTTON BLENDS since the virus can live much longer on those materials and they are harder to clean. Before using, wash the fabric in HOT water and dry in a HOT dryer. If possible, do this two or three times. This will ensure the materials are shrunk completely and the threads are as tightly woven as possible. If you're cutting up fabric to use, say, an old sheet, hem up the edges to keep them from fraying, then wash.
3. Make sure you have a ready supply of these and use ONLY ONCE. After each use, when you take it off, handle it by the rubber bands to pull off your face, unfold it without touching the center part (where you've been breathing through and where the greatest number of contagious particles are) and drop it in soapy water. Remember: soap destroys the virus. Then wash your hands and/or use hand sanitizer.
4. At the end of the week or when you next do laundry, wash the bandannas in HOT water and dry in a HOT dryer -- do not air dry! This ensures any viruses on them will be destroyed. Before taking them out of the dryer, wash your hands or use hand sanitizer, then put directly into a new zip-lock bag. That way they're kept clean until the next use.
5. If you absolutely feel the need to have HEPA protection, you can take vacuum cleaner bags that are HEPA certified and cut them into pieces that will fit this mask. Place the piece on the center of the bandanna before folding so the filter is in the center of the space where you're breathing. Remember that you CAN NOT wash the HEPA filter -- that will destroy its filtering ability.
6. LOVE the idea of using bread wrapper "twisties" to mold around the nose! Another possibility is #14 solid copper wire with the insulation removed.
7. For those who are b*tching and moaning because "there's no seal", that's why God made "DURABLE CLOTH TAPE", found in the first-aid section of the store. It's the stuff you use to make sure large bandages stick to your skin. After you put on the mask, use that to tape the edges of the mask to your face, making sure to overlap the tape at the mask corners. Easy-peazy, you've got a sealed mask.
8. One more time: this is for PROTECTION, *NOT* PREVENTION. Now, let's be careful out there.
snippet.textOriginal:
OK, couple of replies to some of the naysayers, etc.  
1. This is NOT the face mask to use if you're doing surgery.  The IS the face mask to use when you're going out to get groceries, etc.  The key word is PROTECTION, **NOT** PREVENTION.  It's not so much to PREVENT you from getting the virus; it's to minimize the chances that you will catch it OR pass it on, if you're asymptomatic.
2. Regardless of if you're using new bandannas or cutting up used clothing or sheets to use, make sure the material is 100% cotton.  DO NOT USE COTTON BLENDS since the virus can live much longer on those materials and they are harder to clean.  Before using, wash the fabric in HOT water and dry in a HOT dryer.  If possible, do this two or three times.  This will ensure the materials are shrunk completely and the threads are as tightly woven as possible.  If you're cutting up fabric to use, say, an old sheet, hem up the edges to keep them from fraying, then wash.
3. Make sure you have a ready supply of these and use ONLY ONCE.  After each use, when you take it off, handle it by the rubber bands to pull off your face, unfold it without touching the center part (where you've been breathing through and where the greatest number of contagious particles are) and drop it in soapy water.  Remember: soap destroys the virus.  Then wash your hands and/or use hand sanitizer.
4. At the end of the week or when you next do laundry, wash the bandannas in HOT water and dry in a HOT dryer -- do not air dry! This ensures any viruses on them will be destroyed. Before taking them out of the dryer, wash your hands or use hand sanitizer, then put directly into a new zip-lock bag.  That way they're kept clean until the next use.
5. If you absolutely feel the need to have HEPA protection, you can take vacuum cleaner bags that are HEPA certified and cut them into pieces that will fit this mask. Place the piece on the center of the bandanna before folding so the filter is in the center of the space where you're breathing.  Remember that you CAN NOT wash the HEPA filter -- that will destroy its filtering ability.
6. LOVE the idea of using bread wrapper "twisties" to mold around the nose!  Another possibility is #14  solid copper wire with the insulation removed.
7. For those who are b*tching and moaning because "there's no seal", that's why God made "DURABLE CLOTH TAPE", found in the first-aid section of the store.  It's the stuff you use to make sure large bandages stick to your skin.  After you put on the mask, use that to tape the edges of the mask to your face, making sure to overlap the tape at the mask corners.  Easy-peazy, you've got a sealed mask.
8. One more time: this is for PROTECTION, **NOT** PREVENTION.  Now, let's be careful out there.

snippet.textDisplay:
From the CDC website:
HCP use of homemade masks:
In settings where facemasks are not available, HCP might use homemade masks (e.g., bandana, scarf) for care of patients with COVID-19 as a last resort. However, homemade masks are not considered PPE, since their capability to protect HCP is unknown. Caution should be exercised when considering this option. Homemade masks should ideally be used in combination with a face shield that covers the entire front (that extends to the chin or below) and sides of the face.
snippet.textOriginal:
From the CDC website:
HCP use of homemade masks:
In settings where facemasks are not available, HCP might use homemade masks (e.g., bandana, scarf) for care of patients with COVID-19 as a last resort. However, homemade masks are not considered PPE, since their capability to protect HCP is unknown. Caution should be exercised when considering this option. Homemade masks should ideally be used in combination with a face shield that covers the entire front (that extends to the chin or below) and sides of the face.

snippet.textOriginal: Aren't these not that efficient due to lack of filtration soince to actually filter out microorganism the filter must be at 0.2 microns. The virus is at a micron measurable level so it would just pass through these masks unfiltered since standard fabric isnt made to filter that small.

snippet.textDisplay: for some reason the WHO and CDC recommendations STILL haven't offered any useful guidelines for the general public to make our own, but anyone who wants to step it up can make a filter to slip inside this with items they might already have at home, by cutting up a HEPA vacuum bag, HVAC filter (a bit more of hassle but works), or even coffee filters, paper towels, kleenex tissues, etc..  obviously it's not going to be the same as an N95, but definitely effective in slowing the contagion rate among the general public.
